newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore stocks firm as Sing dollar stabilises.
newsitem.headline: Singapore stocks firm as Sing dollar stabilises.

text.p: Singapore stocks were firmer at mid-morning on Monday as the Singapore dollar took a breather from recent falls, dealers said.
"There is still some concern over regional currencies but there is this perception that downside (on the stock market) is limited," said a dealer with a local institution.
Dealers said the market was hoping Singapore's June non-oil export data, due for release later in the day, would lend support.

At 0230 GMT, the Straits Times Industrials Index rose 11.25 points to 1,935.48. The Singapore dollar appeared to have steadied at 1.4627/37 compared to a low of 1.4665 on Friday, underpinned by an increase in interbank interest rates in Singapore.
Total turnover was a moderate 68.5 million shares, with 142 gainers to 71 losers.
A mixed bag of small-capitalised stocks dominated trade.
Plastic injection maker AsiaMatrix, whose shares resumed trading on Monday fter a suspension ended by a takeover bid announcement, topped the actives with more than 14 million shares changing hands.
A private firm announced a takeover bid for 50.98 percent of AsiaMatrix its shares at S$1.45 each. The shares rose 25 cents to Singapore $1.63 against its pre-suspension close of S$1.38 on June 27.
Book publisher Popular Holding hit a new high of S$0.60 on a turnover of 4.8 million shares on its earnings prospects.
Dealers said U.S. dollar-denominated stocks continued to fare well, notably small-capitalised manufacturing stocks.
"A weaker Sing dollar is benficial to the manufacturing export companies," said another dealer.
Selected banking blue chips saw some value-hunting following recent losses.
